journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

article-meta.aff: Institute for Applied Mechanics, Technical University of Munich, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Friedrich Pfeiffer, Institute for Applied Mechanics, Technical University of Munich, Boltzmannstrasse 15, D-85747 Garching, Germany. Email: pfeiffer@amm.mw.tum.de

abstract.p: Contacts include the properties contact/detachment and stick/slip. In multibody systems, these features generate a combinatorial problem of large order. It can be solved by the introduction of the complementarity idea, which relates relative kinematics and constraint forces in a contact by inequality constraints in a non-smooth way. Mathematically, these complementarity inequalities can be replaced by an augmented Lagrange approach applying methods from set theory. This article gives a survey of this evolution. It presents the theoretical fundaments for such systems and considers some practical examples of industrial relevancy.

sec.title: Phenomena
sec.p: Constraints represent the glue of mechanical or biomechanical systems. A complete set of constraints is the most abstract representation of a machine's functions, at least in the sense of kinematical requirements. We are accustomed to regard in most cases bilateral constraints, which, as a matter of fact, represent only this part of the mechanical world. But the technical world includes as much unilateral constraints in the form of contacts as there are bilateral ones. Therefore, it makes sense to consider also this unilateral dynamical world of constraining connections.

Contacts may be closed, and the contact partners may detach again. Within a closed contact, we might have sliding or stiction, both features connected with local friction. If two bodies come into contact, they usually penetrate into each other, leading to local deformations. If contacts are accompanied by tangential forces and tangential relative velocities within the contact plane, we get, in addition to normal, also the tangential deformations. Depending on the dynamical (or statical) environment, contacts may change their state, from closure to detachment, from sliding to stiction, and vice versa. We call a contact active if it is closed or if we have stiction; otherwise, we call a contact passive.

Active contacts always exhibit contact forces which, in the general case of normal and tangential deformations, follow from the local material properties of the colliding bodies, from the external (with respect to the contact) dynamics (statics) and external forces. Considering contacts that leads to complicated problems of continuum mechanics which, as a rule must be solved by numerical algorithms like finite element method (FEM) or boundary element method (BEM). For the treatment of dynamical problems, this approach is too costly and in many cases also not adequate. The rigid body approach gives quicker results and applies better to large dynamical systems.

Under rigid body approach, we understand that a contact behaviour characterized at least in the local contact zone by no deformations and thus by rigid body properties. The contact process is then governed by certain contact laws like those of Newton and Poisson and appropriate extensions of them. A fundamental law with respect to rigid body models is the complementarity rule, sometimes called corner's law or Signorinis's law. It states that in contact dynamics, either relative kinematical quantities are zero and the accompanying constraint forces or constraint force combinations are not zero, or vice versa. For a closed contact, the relative normal distance and normal velocity of the colliding bodies are zero and the constraint force in normal direction is not zero, or vice versa. For stiction, the tangential relative velocity is zero, and the constraint force is located within the friction cone, which means that the difference of the static friction force and constraint force is not zero, or vice versa. The resulting inequalities are indispensable for an evaluation of the transitions between the various contact states.

From these properties follows a well-defined indicator behavior giving the transition phases. For normal passive contacts, the normal relative distance and velocity of the colliding bodies indicate the contact state. If the distance becomes zero, the contact will be active, the indicator ‘relative distance’ becomes a constraint accompanied by a constraint force. The end of an active contact is then indicated by the constraint force. If it changes sign, indicating a change from pressure to tension, we get detachment, and the contact again transits to a passive state.

In the case of friction, we have in the passive state a non-vanishing tangential relative velocity as an indicator. If it becomes zero, there might be a transition from sliding to stiction, depending on the force balance within or on the friction cone. The indicator ‘relative tangential velocity’ then becomes a constraint leading to tangential constraint forces. The contact remains active as long as the maximum static friction force is larger than the constraint force, which means that there is a force balance within the friction cone. If this ‘friction saturation’ becomes zero, the contact again might go into a passive state with non-zero tangential relative velocity.

If we deal with multibody systems (MBSs) including unilateral constraints, the problem of multiple contacts and their interdependences arises. A straightforward solution of these processes would come out with a combinatorial problem of huge dimension. Therefore, a formulation applying complementarity rules and the resulting inequalities is a must. The mathematical methods developed in that area in the past 20 years assure nearly always an unambiguous solution, even in the cases of mutually dependent contacts.

In no way we should forget the pioneering work of our predecessors at the beginning of the mechanical sciences. They had really astonishing good ideas about friction and impacts, generally about non-smooth features. To give only a few examples, we may remember Leonardo da Vinci and his experiments on frictional effects resulting in two laws completely compatible with our knowledge, and this was about 200 years before Newton and his force definition. Amontons1 rediscovered these laws, which a bit later were put in a form we use them today by Coulomb.2 Fourier3 and Boltzmann4 considered unilateral behaviour within the framework of mechanical principles, and Hertz5 developed some famous laws concerning impacts. But then, a real revival of these early research efforts took place in the second half of the last century.

Since the beginning of the field in the 1970s and 1980s, mainly pushed by scientists like Moreau6 and Panagiotopoulos,7 very large progress has been made with respect to not only the theoretical and the mathematical formulation, but also large applications in industry. Good representations of these evolution processes may be found, for example in the books of Acary,8 Brogliato,9 Fremond,10 Glocker,11 Leine,12 Pfeiffer13 and Wriggers.14

sec.title: Some references
sec.p: The field of multibody dynamics with unilateral contacts must be seen before the background of various research activities in the area of variational inequalities in connection with convex energy functions on the one side15–18 and in the area of hemivariational inequalities in connection with non-convex energy functions.7 Both areas are young, the first one being around 40 years and the second only around 20 years old. The two scientists who are the most connected with this development are Moreau in Montpellier, France, and Panagiotopoulos in Thessaloniki, Greece. Moreau started already in the 1970s to formulate the non-continuous properties of non-smooth mechanics,6,16,19 and not much later Panagiotopoulos considered inequality problems17 which led him consistently to the development of hemivariational inequalities.7 Most non-smooth mechanical problems possess non-convex features. Nearly all applications at that time were of statical or quasi-statical nature.

In Sweden, Lötstedt20,21 considered a series of practical examples and established a school, which in more recent time has been continued very successfully by Klarbring22,23 and his group. Klarbring also treats statical and quasi-statical problems with applications to FEM.

The sphere of influence of these scientists increases since the significance of the area has been noticed. Especially, Jean and Moreau24 give an excellent contribution to dry friction, also in connection with frictional impacts. The book15 presents a proof with respect to the existence of Jean's and Moreau's impact theory. A very good survey on this topic may be found in Brogliato.25 In the meantime, literature is increasing considerably, therefore only a few examples are given.

The papers26,27 deal with a two-dimensional contact including dry friction. The resulting linear complementarity problem (LCP) is solved by a modified Simplex-algorithm. The authors28,29 study the self-excitation of frictional vibrations. Frictional constraints are described by variational inequalities and evaluated on the basis of measured friction characteristics. The paper30 discusses among other topics also the existence of unambiguous solutions for the generalized accelerations concerning frictional contact problems, a question by the way, which also has been regarded in Lötstedt.20,21

Non-smooth mechanics allows a general theoretical description, but relevant problems must be solved numerically. Many valuable contributions to the numerics of non-continuous systems8,31 are still extremely time-consuming. As was indicated above, we get for plane contacts a linear and for spatial contacts a non-linear complementarity problem (NCP). For LCPs, solution procedures exist31 on the basis of extended linear programming theories. The existence of a solution is assured. For NCPs various approximations have been suggested22,23,32 and applied to practical problems.33–42 The algorithms work in most cases convincingly, but the computing times explode because of the iterative character of nearly all solution methods. An excellent survey of all kinds of numerical methods in the non-smooth field is given by Brogliato et al.43

As very often, the numerical problems could considerably be reduced by new formulations of the mechanical problem itself, namely the multibody dynamics problem including unilateral constraints. Moreau6 himself has suggested to apply measure differential equations (MDEs). They contain a Lebesgue-measurable part for the continuous components and an atomic part based on a Dirac point measure for the impact parts. They can conveniently be solved by a time-stepping algorithm based on time-discretization of the equations of motion, together with the unilateral constraints by implicit and explicit Euler formulas. In spite of the advantages of the MDEs and of the time-stepping routines, we are still left with problems for large systems, especially with respect to spatial contact configurations including friction and with respect to systems undergoing impacts with friction simultaneously. But as a whole, time stepping in combination with an LCP formulation works well for many practical problems.

A completely different approach uses the augmented Lagrangian.44 A very good description is given by Leine and Nijmeijer,12 which also shows that the augmented Lagrangian method in optimization theory is identical to the exact regularization method. The augmented Lagrangian method transforms differential inclusions for set-valued force laws to a set of non-smooth continuous algebraic equations, which might be solved by a root-finding algorithm. The above mentioned time-stepping method can be combined with the augmented Lagrangian method for integrating the set of non-smooth non-linear equations resulting from the evaluation process including the augmented Lagrange function and the relevant optimization procedure. The article44 is a second typical example of reformulating a mechanical problem, in this case the unilateral constraint problem, by introducing new ideas from mathematics, in this case from set-theory, which as a matter of fact possesses a certain affinity to multibody dynamics with set-valued force laws.11

The author's former institute prosecuted applied and engineering mechanics and was involved in unilateral problems since the 1980s exclusively in connection with multibody dynamics. The fundaments of that area might be found in Bremer45 and Bremer and Pfeiffer46 which present multibody theory on the basis of the projection method, yielding the most efficient theory for multibody applications. In the course of the years and very much due to practical requirements, this type of multibody theory has been combined with inequality formulations to describe the unilateral behaviour of multiple contacts.47–49 Especially, the already mentioned complementarity properties in combination with the kinematics and kinetics of the appropriate indicators were the main keys for a consistent description of MBSs with many unilateral contacts.49 An extension to impacts before the background of Moreau's work was then straightforward.50,51 The corresponding theory has recently and successfully been confirmed by extensive measurements.52

Based on these fundaments, a large variety of industrial applications has been considered. The paper53 and the dissertation54 deal with roller chains very often used in automotive industry. Roller chains typically possess some hundred degrees of freedom (DOFs) and hundreds of contacts, where also stick–slip processes take place in the chain–wheel contacts. Chains used for continuous variable transmissions (CVTs) do not have such a large amount of DOFs but particularly difficult spatial contacts within the conic wheel discs. Even efficiencies have been evaluated with an excellent agreement of theory and measurements.37,38,55 Another area of application is the field of assembly processes in manufacturing, where during mating processes contacts are closed and detached, and stick–slip phenomena (up to jamming) occur. Large efforts have been made to describe in a very general way the relative kinematics of colliding bodies in terms of differential geometry.56 The results were convincing. They are now used in all other applications.

Another example of manufacturing concerns vibration conveyors which are very often used to transport, orient and select small parts like screws, bolts, electronic components etc. Without the theory on MBSs with unilateral contacts, a treatment of such a machine would have been impossible. The dissertation42 solves this problem theoretically and proves it experimentally.41
In the following sections, we shall give a survey of the theory including impacts with friction, and we shall present some typical applications.

sec.title: Models
sec.p: By models we mean the mechanical, especially the dynamical, behaviour of our system under consideration expressed by the laws of kinematics and kinetics. This leads to a mathematical description in the form of non-linear differential equations with inequality constraints, which as a rule must be solved numerically. As we treat MBSs with unilateral contacts, we start with a short representation of elastic multibody dynamics, proceed to contact kinematics in terms of differential geometry and explain the special features of unilateral contact behaviour. We then formulate the equations of motion including the non-smoothness of our system and give finally a survey on impacts with friction described by a newly developed theory.

sec.title: Multibody dynamics
sec.p: The theory of multibody dynamics including interconnected rigid and/or elastic bodies is in the meantime well established and also commercialized to a large extent. Most of the existing computer codes are based on the so-called projection method, which considers the free motion within the hyper-spaces tangential to the constraint surfaces. The Jacobians performing these projections are derivations with respect to the constraint equations usually formulated on a velocity level.13,45,57 As the equations of motion for MBSs represent the basis for all further unilateral considerations, we shall give a short survey.

We consider an MBS with f DOFs which we later shall subdivide in ‘rigid’ and ‘elastic’ DOFs. Applying the principle of virtual power (Jourdain) we get (1) where Rvi ∈ IR3, Rai ∈ IR3 are the absolute velocity, acceleration of body i in a body-fixed reference system, Rfi ∈ IR3 all forces applied to body i, q·∈I-3muRf the generalized velocities and mi is the mass of body i. The velocity and acceleration vectors must be evaluated in a body-fixed frame which yields (Figure 1) (2) The following abbreviations are used (index i always omitted):v = RvA

Combining equations (1) and (2) and the above abbreviations, we come out with the following set of equations of motion (3) where elastic influences are regarded as shown in Figure 1. The radius vector r from an inertial frame (I) to a mass element dmi of the deformed body Bi can be written as (4) where rIR is the vector from (I) to (R), x0 the vector to the mass element in the undeformed configuration and r¯el the displacement vector. As in most cases of technical relevancy, we assume that the elastic displacements of the components are very small compared to their geometric dimensions.

This allows the introduction of a Ritz approach for the elastic deformation57 (5) with (qel∈I-3muRnel)i and (W∈I-3muR3,nel)i. This well-known superposition of Ansatz or shape functions wji(x0) requires their completeness property.57 These shape functions might be evaluated by measurements, FEM calculations and analytic approaches, or they might be approximated by cubic spline systems. Anyway, they must be in accordance with the elastic behaviour of the system.

Combining equations (3) to (5), we must consider the dependencies a(q··), ω·(q··), q··el,i(q··) which says that all absolute and elastic accelerations depend on the generalized accelerations q··. This property can be expressed by (6) (7) The equations (3) to (7) can now be put into the form (8) After lengthy and tedious calculations, it is always possible to bring equation (8) into a standard form, which we need for all further considerations. It is written as (9) Equation (9) include all bilateral constraints. They represent the maximum number of minimal (generalized) coordinates, and from this all unilateral contacts are in a state that they do not block any further DOF. If some of the unilateral constraints become active, then the remaining number of DOFs is smaller than f.

sec.title: Contact kinematics
sec.p: Geometry and kinematics are the fundaments for establishing models of dynamical systems. In the case of unilateral contacts, this is especially important, because magnitudes of relative kinematics serve as indicators for passive contacts and as constraints for active contacts (`Introduction' section). As most of the applications require more or less arbitrary body contours, it makes sense to derive the kinematical contact equations in a general form applying well-known rules of the differential geometry of surfaces.49,50,56

In practice, we find two types of contacts, two- and three-dimensional ones. For the two-dimensional case, the contacting bodies lie in a plane, thus defining a contact line with given direction. Only the sense of direction has to be determined. Problems of that kind are connected with linear complementarity.

For the three-dimensional case, the contacting bodies have a spatial form, and the contact takes place in a plane allowing two tangential directions. The resulting direction for the contact process is not known beforehand and usually must be determined iteratively. Problems of that kind are connected with non-linear complementarity.

sec.title: Plane contact kinematics
sec.p:
Plane contact kinematics has been presented in the dissertation50 and since then applied to many practical problems (see also Pfeiffer and Glocker49). We start with the geometry of a single body as indicated in Figure 2. We assume a convex contour and describe it by a parameter s. Connecting with s a moving trihedral (t, n, b) and introducing a body-fixed frame B, we write (10) For planar contours, the binormal Bb is constant. Therefore (11) Figure 2.
Planar contour geometry.

On the other hand, the absolute changes of n and t are given by the Coriolis equation (12) where we must keep in mind that BωIB = BΩ for body-fixed frames B. Substituting equation (11) into (12), we get a coordinate-free representation of the overall changes n·,t·. (13) which we can evaluate in any basis. The main advantage of equation (13) consists of the eliminated, frame-dependent differentiations Bn· and Bt·.

In the same manner, we proceed with the contour vector rPΣ. According to equations (11) and (12), we write (14) and eliminate Br·PΣ. Then, we get the absolute changes of rPΣ (15) Due to vΣ=vP+r·PΣ, the absolute velocity of the moving contour point is given by (16) where (17) The velocity vC results from rigid body kinematics and corresponds to the velocity of a body-fixed point at the contour. From equations (16) and (17), we see that (18)
