Only the part (21) corresponds to such an acceleration, so we can write (22)

Later, we have to determine the relative velocities of contact points in the normal and tangential directions and their time derivatives. For this purpose, we introduce the scalars (23) and state their derivatives as (24) With n·,t· from equation (13), v·C=aC from equation (22), and noting nTΩ~t=bTΩ, tTΩ~t=0 we derive (25)

With this basis, we are able to derive the relative kinematics of two bodies such as relative distances, relative velocities and accelerations. Without going into details and referring especially to Pfeiffer and Glocker,49 we summarize the following relationships (Figure 3). Figure 3.
General orientation of two bodies.

Potential contact points can be characterized by (26) (27) From each set, we need only one equation. The relative distance gN is (28) Since the normal vectors always point inward, gN is positive for separation and negative for overlapping. Therefore, a changing sign of gN from positive to negative indicates a transition from initially separated bodies to contact.

With these equations and considering Figure 3, we derive the relative velocities in normal and tangential directions (29) where vC1, vC2 are the absolute velocities of the potential contact points C1, C2. These velocities might be expressed by the generalized velocities q· and some Jacobians JC1, JC2 to give (30) Substituting equation (29) into equation (30) yields (31) with (32) which we use in the following equations as a representation of the relative velocities. It may be noticed here that a negative value of ġN corresponds to an approaching process of the bodies and coincides at vanishing distance gN = 0 with the relative velocity in the normal direction before an impact. In the case of a continual contact (gN = ġN = 0), the term ġT shows the relative sliding velocity of the bodies, which we can use to determine the time points of transitions from sliding (ġT ≠ 0) to sticking or rolling (ġT = 0).
The relevant accelerations follow from a further time differentiation. (33) where wN, wT are given by equation (32), and w¯n,w¯T are (34) with
The angular velocities Ω1, Ω2 relate to the two contacting bodies (Figures 2 and 3).

sec.title: Spatial contact kinematics
sec.p:
Spatial contact kinematics has been presented in the dissertation56 and since then applied to many practical problems. The situation in this case is of course more complex. We still assume that the two approaching bodies are convex (Figure 4) at least in that area where contact points might occur. The two bodies are moving with vi, Ωi (i = 1, 2). For the description of a surface Σ, we need two parameters s and t : rΣ = rΣ(s, t). The tangents s and t, which span the tangent plane at a point of the surface, are defined as (35) Figure 4.
Contact geometry of two surfaces.
From these basic vectors, the fundamental magnitudes of the first order are calculated (36) The normalized normal vector n is perpendicular to the tangent plane and pointing outwards (37)

We further need the fundamental magnitudes of the second order (38) For a contact point we require, that the normal vector of body 1 (n1) and the distance vector rD are perpendicular to the tangent vectors of body 2 (s2 and t2). Thus, we obtain four non-linear equations (39) This non-linear problem has to be solved at every time step of the numerical integration. After the solution is found, the distance gN between the possible contact points can be calculated as (40) gN is used as an indicator for the contact state. Its value is positive for ‘no contact’ and negative for penetration. The constraints are again formulated on velocity level, where in the spatial case we have three of them, one in normal direction ġN and two in the tangential directions ġS, ġT (41) with vΣ1 and vΣ2 being defined in an analogous way as in equation (30). Differentiating these equations with respect to time leads to the constraints on acceleration level (42) The time derivatives of the contact point velocities vΣ1 and vΣ2 can be written in the form (43) The vectors n·1,s·1 and t·1 are determined by the formulas of Weingarten and Gauss, which express the derivatives of the normal vector and the tangent vectors in terms of the basic vectors (44) (45) (46)
The definition of the Christoffel symbols Γαβ σ, α, β, σ = 1, 2, can be found in standard textbooks. Substituting equations (45) and (46) in equation (42) yields the constraint equations (47)

As can be seen, these equations depend only on the Jacobians with respect to the contact points JΣ1, JΣ2, the basic vectors of the surfaces and the time derivatives of the contour parameters s·1,t·1,s·2,t·2. The Jacobians are known from the rigid body algorithm, the basic vectors from the surface description. The time derivatives of the contour parameters can be calculated by deriving equation (39) with respect to time (48) which means that the conditions for the contact point should not change while the two bodies are moving. Evaluating equation (48), we obtain a system of equations which are linear in the derivatives of the contour parameters (49) This linear problem has to be solved at every time step of numerical integration. Let us summarize the constraint equations in the well-known form, by rewriting equation (47) (50) The terms in equation (47), which are linearly dependent on q··, are collected in the constraint vectors wN, wS and wT, the rest is included in the scalars w¯N,w¯S,w¯T.

sec.title: Multiple unilateral contacts
sec.p: Research on non-smooth MBSs with unilateral contacts started in the 1980s and 1990s from physical, mechanical considerations, which are straightforward and easy to apply. A typical example of this type of research is complementarity. A contact is closed, relative kinematics is zero and a corresponding constraint force is generated, which defines an ‘active constraint’, or vice versa: a contact is open with some relative kinematics but no constraint force, which defines a ‘passive contact’.

The mathematical formulations have become much more efficient and compact applying set-theoretical approaches, altogether very well suited for a numerical treatment. The price for these tendencies is a reduction of physical and mechanical insight. We shall present in the first part the classical approach as developed in the 1990s and in the second part the more recent approaches. In simulating non-smooth MBSs, we still have to start with classical mathematics of kinematics, kinetics and of the constraining structures.

sec.title: Classical approach
sec.p: Multiple contacts in MBSs include a combinatorial problem of large dimensions. If the state in one contact changes, for example from contact to detachment or from slip to stick, all other contacts are also influenced which makes a search for a new set of contact configurations necessary. To not prosecute the combinatorial process, we need extended contact laws which describe unambiguously the transitions for the possible contact states and which generate only consistent contact configurations. In a first step we define all contact sets, which can be found in MBS49 (51)

These sets describe the kinematic state of each contact point. The set IA consists of nA indices of all contact points. As an example we consider equation (9). It belongs to the set combination IA∖{IC, IN, IT}. The elements of the set IC are the nC indices of the unilateral constraints with vanishing normal distance gNi = 0, but arbitrary relative velocity in the normal direction. In the index set IN are the nN indices of the potentially active normal constraints which fulfil the necessary conditions for continuous contact (vanishing normal distance gNi = 0 and no relative velocity ġNi in the normal direction). The index set IN includes, for example, all contact states with slipping. The nT elements of the set IT are the indices of the potentially active tangential constraints. The corresponding normal constraints are closed and the relative velocities ġTi in the tangential direction are zero. The numbers of elements of the index sets IC, IN and IT are not constant because there are variable states of constraints due to separation and stick–slip phenomena.

As a next step, we must organize all transitions from contact to detachment and from stick to slip and the corresponding reversed transitions. In normal direction of a contact, we find the following situation:49
passive contact i gNi(g, t) ≥ 0, λNi = 0, indicator gNi
transition to contact gNi(g, t) = 0, λNi ≥ 0
active contact i gNi(g, t) = 0, λNi > 0, indicator λNi, constraint (gNi = 0)
transition to detachment
(52)

The kinematical magnitudes gNi,g·Ni,g··Ni are given with equations (28), (31) and (33) and (40), (41) and (50), where g·Ni,g··Ni are needed when we go to a velocity or an acceleration level. The constraint forces λNi must be compressive forces. If they change sign, we get separation. The properties of equation (52) establish a complementarity behavior which might be expressed by nN (set IN) complementarity conditions (put on an acceleration level) (53) The variational inequality (54) is equivalent to the complementary conditions in equation (53). The convex set (55) contains all admissible contact forces λNi * in the normal direction.39,49

The complementarity problem defined in equation (53) might be interpreted as a corner law which requires for each contact g··Ni≥0,λNi≥0,g··NiλNi=0. Figure 5 illustrates this property. Figure 5.
Corner law for normal contacts (Signorini's law).

With respect to the tangential direction of a contact, we shall confine our considerations to the application of Coulomb's friction law which in no way means a loss of generality. The complementary behaviour is a characteristic feature of all contact phenomena independent of the specific physical law of contact. Furthermore, we assume that within the infinitesimal small time step for a transition from stick to slip and vice versa, the coefficients of static and sliding frictions are the same, which may be expressed by (56)

For ġTi ≠ 0, any friction law may be applied (Figure 6). With this property, Coulomb's friction law distinguishes between the two cases (57) Equation (57) formulates the mechanical property that we are within the friction cone if the relative tangential velocity is zero and the tangential constraint force |λTi| is smaller than the maximum static friction force (μ0iλNi). Then, we have stiction. We are on the friction cone if we slide with |g·Ti|>0. At a transition point, the friction force is then (μ0iλNi) (equation 57). In addition, we must regard the fact that in the tangential contact plane, we might get one or two directions according to a plane or a spatial contact. From this we summarize in the following way:
passive contact i (sliding, set IN\IT) |g·Ti|≥0,|μ0iλNi|-|λTi|=0, indicator |g·Ti|
transition slip to stick |g·Ti|=0,|μ0iλNi|-|λTi|≥0
active contact i (sticking, set IT) |g·Ti|=0,|μ0iλNi|-|λTi|>0, indicator |μ0iλNi| − |λTi|, constraint |g·Ti|=0
transition stick to slip |g·Ti|≥0,|μ0iλNi|-|λTi|=0
Figure 6.
Typical friction characteristic.

From a numerical standpoint of view, we have to check the indicator for a change of sign, which then requires a subsequent interpolation. For a transition from stick to slip, one must examine the possible development of a non-zero relative tangential acceleration as a start for sliding.

Equation (57) that put on an acceleration level can then be written in a more detailed form (58) This contact law may be represented by a double corner law, as indicated in Figure 7. To transform the law (58) for tangential constraints into a complementarity condition we must decompose the double corner into single ones. A decomposition into four elementary laws is given in50 a decomposition into two elements in Rossman and Pfeiffer33 and Rossman.34 In any case we come out with a complementarity problem of the form (59) where n* = nN + 4nT in the case of decomposition into four and n* = nN + 2nT for a decomposition into two elementary corners. The quantity x includes the contact forces and one part of the decomposed accelerations, the quantity y the relative accelerations and in addition the friction saturation defined as the difference of static friction force and tangential constraint force (μ0iλNi − |λTi|). Equation (59) describes an LCP, thus being adequate for plane contacts. In the case of spatial contacts, the friction saturation contains the geometric sum of two possible friction directions leading to a nonlinearity which cannot be solved in a straightforward way. Solution procedures are discussed in many works.13,22,23,44,58 Figure 7.
Corner law for tangential constraints.

Similar as in the normal case, we can represent the contact law equation (58) by a variational inequality of the form11,12 (60) The convex set CTi contains all admissible contact forces λTi * in tangential direction (61)

For a derivation of the equations of motion including unilateral effects, we must combine the multibody equations (9) with the unilateral constraints (33) or (50) and (58). In a first step, we include the constraint forces into equation (9) keeping in mind that in a system with additional unilateral constraints, the number of DOFs is variable. To avoid difficulties with many different sets of minimal coordinates, we take one set of generalized coordinates (eq. (9) for the combination (IA∖Ic), (IA∖IN), (IA∖IT), see equation (51)) and consider the active unilateral constraints as additional constraints which necessarily are accompanied by constraint forces. We include these constraint forces, which are in fact the contact forces, into the equations of motion (9) by a Lagrange multiplier technique.

The constraint vectors wNi and wTi in equations (33) and (50) are arranged as columns in the constraint matrices (62) for all active constraints. The constraint matrices are transformation matrices from the space of constraints to the configuration space. The transposed matrices are used for the transition from the configuration space to the space of constraints.

The contact forces have the amounts λNi (normal forces) and the components λTi1 and λTi2 (tangential forces). These elements are combined in the vectors of constraint forces (63) with λTi(t) = [λTi1(t), λTi2(t)]T. In general, the contact forces are time-varying quantities. By the constraint vectors and matrices in equation (50), the contact forces can be expressed in the configuration space. These forces are then added to equation (9) to give (64)

For the index sets see equation (51). The contact forces λTi in equation (64) can be passive forces of sticking contacts or active forces of sliding contacts. We express the tangential forces of the nN − nT sliding contacts by the corresponding normal forces using Coulomb's friction law by (65) where the coefficients μi(|g·Ti|) of sliding friction may depend on time. The negative sign relates to the opposite direction of relative velocity and friction force. The sliding forces of equation (64) in the configuration space are then (66)

A substitution of these forces into equation (64) yields the equations of motion (67) with the additional contact forces as Lagrange multipliers. The matrices WN and WT contain components from the equations (33) or (50). The matrix HR∈I-3muRf,nN of the sliding contacts has the same dimension as the constraint matrix WN. For nT ≤ nN, HR consists of the nN − nT columns
while the other nT columns contain only zero elements.

The relative accelerations of the active normal and tangential constraints in the equation (33) or (50) can be combined by means of the constraint matrices (62) in the matrix notation. Together with equation (67) we get the system of equations (68)

The unknown quantities are the generalized accelerations q··∈I-3muRf, the contact forces in the normal direction λN ∈IRnN and in the tangential direction λN∈I-3muRnN, as well as the corresponding relative accelerations g··N∈I-3muRnN and g··T∈I-3muR2nT. For the determination of the f + 2(nN + 2nT) quantities, we have now up to f + nN + 2nT equations. The system of equation (69) will be completed by including the missing nN + 2nT contact laws. In general, the kinematic equations are dependent on each other if there is more than one contact point per rigid body. The situation results in linearly dependent columns of the constraint matrices WN, WT in equation (68). Such constraints are called dependent constraints.

Before including the contact laws, we shall evaluate the equation (68) a bit further. Introducing the magnitudes (69) we can write equation (68) (70) Outside the transition events and thus for a not changing contact configuration, the relative accelerations g·· are zero. In this case, equation (70) has a solution for g·· and λ, which is written as (71) The first equation of (71) may also be expressed in the form Aλ + b = 0 with A and b following from (72).

We combine now the equations of motion in the form (68) with the contact equations (54) and (60) which results in the following set containing all unilateral processes in the contacts under consideration (72)

The system (72) is not solvable in this form. Therefore, the variational inequalities are transformed into equalities. From this, we get a non-linear system of equations which represent LCPs or NCPs depending on the type of contact, i.e. plane or spatial contacts. LCP can be solved by algorithms related to linear programming methods; for example, Lemke's algorithm, NCPs require iterative algorithms.22,31

sec.title: Recent approaches
sec.p: With ‘recent approaches’, we mainly understand the evolution of the augmented Lagrange method in combination with Moreau's MDEs of motion and the introduction of set-theoretical methods by Alart/Curnier for example. It is typical for such research efforts that the basic contributions were performed quite early, but the realization and application took years of time.

Moreau6 suggested MDEs representing the equations of motion for systems with non-continuous phenomena. These equations contain a Lebesgue-measurable part for the continuous components and an atomic part based on a Dirac point measure for the impact parts (see also Glocker11). They write with u=q· (73) The measure for the velocities du=u·dt+(u+-u-)dη is split in a Lebesgue-measurable part u·dt, which is continuous, and the atomic parts which occur at the discontinuity points with the left and right limits u+ and u− and the Dirac point measure dη. Similarly, the measure for the impulses is defined as dΛ = λdt + Λdη.

In addition to this more general approach for the equations of motion, we introduce a novel concept for the inequality constraints which originally comes from the linear programming field. It applies the proximal point idea from convex analysis18 to develop the so-called ‘Augmented Lagrange Method’.44 The proximal point of a convex set C to a point z is the closest point in C to z12 (74) which is illustrated in Figure 8. If we understand this convex set as the cut of a friction cone with different friction coefficients in the two contact directions, then every solution of the system falling outside the convex set is brought back to the boundary of the set. In the case of a complementarity in normal direction (contact/detachment-case) the set is just the half space with non-negative constraint forces λN. Therefore, we get the relations (75) where CN denotes the set of admissible normal contact forces (76) In the same manner, we can put Coulomb's friction law into the form (77) with CT denoting the set of admissible tangential forces (78) At this point, we have to discuss the above expressions in more detail. We follow partly the very clear description of convex properties in the book of Leine.12 He interprets the basic relationship for the constraints [λ = proxC(λ − rg)] as an ‘exact regularization’, where r is the steepness parameter of this regularization. The above expression replaces the non-smooth contact laws by a prox-function, which is usually non-linear, but which allows at the same time to reduce the whole system of the equations of motion together with the inequality constraints to a point mapping set. It can be treated by modern but well-known numerical methods, as we shall discuss. Figure 8.
The proximal point in convex analysis.

Coming back to the expression [λ = proxC(λ − rg)], we see by a more heuristic consideration the following features: the relation can be satisfied only by left-hand and right-hand side expressions of equal sign or by left-hand and right-hand side expressions, which are zero. From this we may conclude the following results for a holonomic case59 (79)

The first case corresponds to an active contact with contact and no detachment, or it corresponds for the case (g→g·) to an active tangential contact with stiction. The second case corresponds to a passive contact state. A more thorough consideration with respect to the equivalence of complementarities and the prox representation may be found in Alart and Curnier44 and Leine and Nijmeijer.12

Combining the contact laws (75) and (77) together with the equations of motion (73), we obtain a set of non-smooth continuous equations for the unknowns q··, λN and λT (80) which is a convenient form for applying the time-stepping algorithm together with the augmented Lagrange idea for a numerical solution.73

sec.title: General theory
sec.p: Impacts with and without friction play an important role in many machines and mechanisms. They were a research topic at the author's former institute since many years starting with impacts without friction47 and finally proceeding to a theory which describes impacts with friction in a rather general way.11,50,51 This new theory has convincingly been verified by a large variety of experiments performed by Beitelschmidt.52 We shall give a short survey. As a matter of fact, there have been quite a number of remarkable and significant contributions to this topic, for example Moreau,6 Brogliato25 and Frémond.60

We assume as usual that an impact takes place in an infinitesimal short time and without any change of position, orientation and all non-impulsive forces. Nevertheless and virtually, we zoom the impact time, establish the equations for a compression and an expansion phase and then apply these equations again for an infinitesimal short time interval. The evaluation has to be performed on a velocity level which we realize by formal integration of the equations of motion, the constraints and the contact laws (equation 72). Denoting the beginning of an impact, the end of compression and the end of expansion by the indices A, C, E, respectively, we get for Δt = tE − tA (81) Here ΛNC, ΛTC are the impulses in the normal and tangential directions which are transferred during compression, and ΛNE, ΛTE those of expansion. Defining q·A=q·(tA); q·C=q·(tC); q·E=q·(tE), we express the relative velocities as (82) Considering in a first step the compression phase and combining the equations (81) and (82) we come out with (83) where G is called the matrix of projected inertia. It consists of four blocks GNN, GNT, GTN, GTT. Equation (83) allows to calculate the relative velocities g·NC and g·TC at the end of the compression phase, depending on the velocities at the beginning of the impact g·NA and g·TA under the influence of the contact impulses ΛNC and ΛTC. To calculate these impulses, two impact laws in normal and tangential directions are necessary. As already indicated, magnitudes of relative kinematics and constraint forces (here impulses) are complementary quantities. In normal direction, these are ġNC and ΛNC. In tangential direction, we have the relative tangential velocity vector g·TC and the friction saturation (ΛTC − (diagμi) ΛNC). Decomposing the tangential behaviour we obtain52 (84) Together with equation (83), this results in an LCP in a standard form y = Ax + b with x ≥ 0, y ≥ 0 and xT y = 0 (85) μ is a diagonal matrix, containing the friction coefficients of the contacts. The problem can be solved numerically. The velocities ġNC, ġTC and the impulsions ΛNC, ΛTC are either part of the result or can be obtained by transformation (84) and by TC=TCV (+)-μNC.

In the compression phase, kinetic energy of the colliding bodies is stored as potential energy. During the expansion phase parts of this energy are transformed back. This regaining process is governed by two coefficients of restitution in normal and tangential directions εN and εT, respectively.

In the case of multiple impacts, Poisson's hypothesis does not guarantee impenetrability of the bodies.11 So, the law is enhanced by an additional condition. The normal impulse during phase of restitution ΛNE is in the minimum εEΛNC in each contact, but can be arbitrary high to avoid penetration. In this case, the bodies remain in contact after the impact. This impact law with a complementary character is drawn in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Impact law for the phase of expansion in normal direction.

In tangential direction, the impact law is ruled by three effects: at first, a minimum impulse εTΛTC must be transferred. On the other hand, the impulse must not exceed the friction limit. Usually, it is assumed that between these two limits, the tangential velocity is zero. The measurements of Beitelschmidt52 however indicate a small tangential velocity ġTE0 in this area. It might be produced by the local difference of the contact point and that point where the tangential restoring force due to tangential compression applies. The inclusion of this velocity gives a slight improvement for the comparison theory/measurement. With (86) one can calculate ġTE0 for all contacts and the tangential impact law looks like drawn in Figure 10. εN and εT are diagonal matrices containing the different coefficients for all contacts. Figure 10.
Impact law for the phase of restitution in tangential direction.

To formulate the equation for the phase of restitution as an LCP similar to the compression phase, the two matrices (87) are introduced. After some transformations similar to those of the compression phase, the LCP is written (88) with (89) After solution, the velocities ġNC, ġTC and the impulses ΛNC, ΛTC are either part of the result or can be obtained by the transformations (90) (91) If the impulses during the two phases of the impact are known, one can calculate the motion q·E of the MBS at the end of the impact. (92)

The above impact theory has been verified in Beitelschmidt.52 More than 600 throwing measurements have been performed. Figure 11 depicts a typical result for a material pair PVC/PVC. The comparison with measurements is excellent, as in many other cases. Figure 11.
Dimensionless tangential relative velocity after versus before the impact for a PVC body (γ=g·TA-g·NA,γTE=g·TE-g·NA).

sec.title: Energy considerations
sec.p: All contact processes are accompanied by losses due to the energy conversion mechanisms taking place within the contact zone. The loss of energy is the difference of the total system energy after and before an impact. In terms of the generalized velocities q·, we write (93) These are expressions considering scleronomic systems without an excitation by external kinematical sources and consequently do not take into account the w-terms of equation (82), for example. Using equations (81) to (83), we can express the generalized velocities by the relative velocities ġ in the contacts or by the contact impulses Λ. We get (94) The second term of these two energy equations is a quadratic form and for itself always positive or zero. The matrix G is at least positive semi-definite, which is also true for its inverse G−1. The energy loss has to be negative, which will be decided by the first term of the above relations. If this term is negative or at least zero, the condition ΔT ≤ 0 will hold. Therefore, we shall concentrate on these first terms which is written in more detail (see equation for the matrix G and the abbreviations G-1=G¯, ΔT = ΔT1 + ΔT2 for the two energy terms in equation (94)) (95) To estimate the sign of these terms, we need to look at the contact laws, for example the complementarities of the relations (53) and (58). For this consideration, the second form, of the energy losses is more convenient than the first form; we only have to find out the signs of the expression {g·NE T(ΛNC+ΛNE)+g·TE T(ΛTC+ΛTE)}. For this purpose, we investigate the possible impact cases, namely compression and expansion either with sticking or sliding, which makes altogether four cases under the assumption that we have always contact and no detachment during the impact.

At this point, we must discuss a bit our model concept. We consider the beginning of an impact with index A, a compression phase with index C and an expansion phase with index E, all indices expressing the end of the corresponding phase. Therefore, we get from our model and the evaluations of the preceding sections the C-magnitudes at the end of compression and the E-magnitudes at the end of expansion, the last ones being the magnitudes after the impact. This is all clear, theoretically and experimentally often verified, and gives correct results. For the consideration of an impact, we do not need the internal details of compression and expansion. But we need them for an energy consideration.

We need to know, for example, how and where a transition sticking/sliding or vice versa occurs within the structure of the impact. As we do not have some means to determine that, we say, transitions occur always at the end of the phases compression and expansion in an infinitesimal short instant of time not influencing the impact dynamics but only going from one branch of the corner laws of Figures (5), (7), (9) and (10) to another branch, which means, transitions take place in the corners of the contact laws. This model concept has significant influence on the energy evaluation.

So it can be shown that the first term g·NE T(ΛNC+ΛNE) of the energy equation (95), last line, is not zero due to positive normal impulses (ΛNC + ΛNE) and due to a non-zero end velocity ġNE after the impact, which is physically reasonable for a separation of the two contacting bodies. But on the other hand, sliding during expansion requires a zero normal relative velocity ġNE = 0 in the contact, which makes the above-mentioned term to zero. The solution can only consist in a model concept, where the change from contact to detachment takes place at the very last end of the expansion phase. The (ΛNE) value slips into the corner of Figure (9) allowing the system to build up the necessary separation velocity.

As a result of the last condition of continual contact during the impact, we get for compression and expansion ΛN > 0 and ġN = 0, which is also part of the complementarity equation (53), and therefore simply (96) the sign of which we have to investigate. Before doing so we consider the sliding cases. All sticking cases are governed by set-valued impulse laws, all sliding cases by a single-valued impulse law, the one by Coulomb. Accordingly, the sliding impulse is proportional to the normal constraint impulse and opposite to (ġTk). Therefore (97) For sliding (ġTk) ≠ 0, always, and therefore we get for the second expression of the energy term ΔT1 in equation (96) together with equation (97) the following result (98) due to the fact of continual contact and thus ΛNE > 0. With these results in mind we come to the four impact cases:
sticking during compression, sticking during expansion: The tangential impulses have to be within the appropriate friction cones. The tangential velocities are zero; therefore, we need not to consider the magnitudes of the impulses. For the definitions, see also the Figures 5, 7, 9, 10
sliding during compression, sliding during expansion: Sliding means single-valued impulse laws according to equation (97). Some difficulties will appear for the cases with reversed sliding, that means, with a tangential relative velocity: the sign is different during compression and during expansion. Therefore, we have to consider the two cases without and with tangential reversibility. For the first case, we do not have a change of sign of the relative tangential velocity, which gives sign(ġTC) = sign(ġTE). This comes out with the relations
The case with tangential reversibility is more complicated, because it includes a change of sign of the tangential relative velocity and thus at least an extremely short stiction phase, which we put exactly at the point (end of compression)/(beginning of expansion). The sliding velocity during compression decreases until it arrives at one of the corners of Figure 7; then we get an extremely short shift from this corner to the other one, which allows the contact to build up a tangential velocity with an opposite sign, then valid for the expansion phase. Only by such a short stiction phase, a reversal of tangential velocity is possible. On the other hand, such a transition from stick to slip, as short as it might be, follows the same process as for the next case sticking/sliding. Therefore, it is dissipative
sticking during compression, sliding during expansion: The transition from sticking in compression and sliding in expansion follows the mechanism (Figure 7): if ΛTC ≷ 0, then sliding is only possible for being at the very end of compression on the friction cone boundary with ΛTC = ±diag(μ)ΛNC and ġTC−at ≶ 0 (at = after transition stick-slip). This results always in a negative sign of the expression (g·TE TΛTC). For the rest, we assume a continuation of the signs after going from stick to slip [sign(ġTE) = sign(ġTC−at)]. Then, we arrive at
sliding during compression, sticking during expansion: This case is again simpler, because we get sticking at the end with a zero relative tangential velocity. Therefore, we need not consider the impulses.
summarized result for all cases
One may object that the above considerations assume in the case of multiple impacts the same impact structure for all simultaneously appearing impacts, which is usually not true. But even any combination of the above four cases for simultaneous impacts gives a loss of energy. Practical experience indicates, in addition, that the simultaneous appearance of impacts is extremely scarce, it is an event, which nearly does not happen. Comprehensive presentations of impact structures are presented in many works.10,11,13,25

As a final result, we may state that the above evaluation confirms the physical argument and that any impact processes are accompanied by energy losses. This confirms also the well-known statement of Carnot that ‘in the absence of impressed impulses, the sudden introduction of stationary and persistent constraints that change some velocity reduces the kinetic energy. Hence, by the collision of inelastic bodies, some kinetic energy is always lost’.61

sec.title: Applications
sec.p: Keeping in mind that the real world of mechanics is as much bilateral as it is unilateral, we could expect from the very beginning a large field of applications waiting for being treated by the new methods. Contact systems of any form are widely spread everywhere, concerning machines, transportation, biological systems and much more. In the following sections, we shall give only a few examples which are typical for that kind of problems. At my former institute, we always tried to establish and to maintain a certain balance of theoretical and applied research, allowing a transfer of newest theoretical findings into challenging and large industrial applications.13,74,75,76

Figure 12 may give some impression of that. The evolution of large applications depends on and goes parallel to the evolution of theoretical and numerical methods. And we should not forget that reduction of computing time for simulations is not only a matter of an improvement of numerical algorithms, but also a matter of formulating the whole problem anew and in a more computer-friendly form. Both efforts must come together for achieving a real evolution like in the non-smooth field of mechanics. Thirty years of evolution (Figure 12) means a computing time reduction of a factor 100–1000, depending on the problem. Figure 12.
The evolution of large applications. LCP: linear complementarity problem; NCP: non-linear complementarity problem; MDE: measure differential equation; MBS: multi body system; CVT: continuous variable transmission.
In the following sections, we shall consider only three of the applications as indicated in Figure 12. A rather comprehensive presentation is given by Pfeiffer.13

sec.title: CVT power transmission
sec.p: For technological developments in the field of CVT gears see the SAE publication.62 My former institute started modelling CVTs in the early 1990s considering in a first step CVT rocker pin chains (see for example Pfeiffer13). The dissertation of Srnik38 deals with plane models of the chain and that of Sedlmayr35 with spatial models. The last one allows an out-of-plane investigation of the chain, which is important for the correct evaluation of the chain forces. The models were partly based on the theory as mentioned above, applying the classical form and for the numerical solution on Lemke's algorithm. Computing times started with days for one case and went down to some hours in the course of ongoing research. In the meantime, we are able to optimize rocker pin chains applying a new mathematical optimization algorithm called ‘implicit filtering’.63 Computing times in the order of magnitude of some hours are reasonable, and the results for a certain type of an industrial chain are very promising.

In a second step, we started to model CVT push belts, which are mainly produced by VDT-Bosch in the Netherlands. These belts possess a completely different configuration leading to much more DOFs and to very many unilateral contacts. In a first approach, which started at the end of the 1990s, it was not possible to apply the above theory in a straightforward way, because first, the existing unilateral theories were not so well developed compared with today and second, the numerical algorithms did not exist to simulate such huge problems. Therefore, various approximations were performed by Bullinger64 and Funk65 for the simulation of these push belts. The main idea consists in applying some hierarchical bases to split up the complete frequency range into parts with low, medium and large frequencies on the one side and to apply a Ritz approach for modelling the belt on the other side. The results compared quite well with measurements from industry.

Figure 13 depicts the existing configurations. To illustrate the data of chains and belts, we consider in Table 1 some characteristic values for two typical industrial cases, a LUK chain and a VDT belt. We shall not consider here the Borg-Warner chains (BWD). Taking into account the number of DOF and the number of possible unilateral contacts, we must put the dynamics of chains and belts to the utmost limit of MBSs with unilateral contacts with concern to modelling capabilities, theoretical fundamentals and numerical possibilities. The above indicated new approaches come out with the result that even in the cases of spatial dynamics or transition dynamics characterizing the change of the transmission ratios, computing times are reasonable and allow parameter variations or real optimizations with the goal of design improvement. Figure 13.
The CVT chain and belt configurations. CVT: continuous variable transmission. Table 1.
Typical data of CVT chain and belt.
LUK VDT
Number of elements 63 382
Element length (thickness) 9.85 mm 1.80 mm
Element width 36 mm 29.6 mm
Polygonal frequency 550 Hz 3000 Hz
Elements/second (1000 r/min, i = 1) 550 3000
Lowest eigenfrequency 90 Hz 120 Hz
DOF, plane case ≈200 ≈1300
Contacts, plane case ≈150 >1000
DOF: degree of freedom; CVT: continuous variable transmission.

sec.title: CVT rocker pin chains
sec.p:
The contact situation of the rocker pins is indicated in Figure 14. The deformed rocker pins enter the elastic sheaves and come into unilateral contacts with them. In addition, we have contacts between pins and the elastic plates and partly some rolling without sliding of the two components of a rocker pin itself,35 (Figure 14, pictures on the right). The MBS of the rocker pin chain CVT consists of two movable and two fixed sheaves and nL = 63 chain link bodies. The sheaves as well as the links are elastic. The bodies are interconnected by force elements (see Pfeiffer13 for more details, especially more detailed formulas and figures). Figure 14.
Contact configurations of rocker pins.

The contact forces between the chain and the pulleys cause a considerable deformation of the pulley's sheaves. The eigenfrequency of the sheaves is much higher than the operating frequencies. According to Srnik38 the mass forces of the elastic deformations can be neglected in this case. With an FEM analysis, the sheave deformation can be calculated using the reciprocal theorem of elasticity (Betti/Maxwell). Together with Hooke's law applied at the pin, this results in an LCP in a standard form. The meaning is clear: if the pins get into contact, we have constraint forces, otherwise not.

Both pulley sets have one rotational, two translational in-plane and one axial out-of-plane DOF. The pulley misalignment mainly depends on the transmission ratio i and the length of the chain. In order to limit the contact pressure between pins and sheaves, the disc curvature radius R must have a lower bound, which in our example is 1.7 m.

Each link represents an elastic body, having three translational rigid body DOFs and in addition the elastic DOFs. The angles βL and γL, shown in Figure 14, depend kinematically on the translational position of the successor link. The links are kinematically interconnected between pairs of rocker pins. The elasticity and the translational damping of the joint is taken into account by the link force element whereas the rotational damping and the axial friction between the pair of pins is concentrated in the joint force element. In the link force element, each plate is taken into account as a spring. The effect of moving contact points relative to the plate spring reference points between a rocker pin and an adjoining plate are modelled as a contact torque.

The classical model for both rigid and elastic bodies is the equation (99) with M the mass matrix and q=(qrigid T,qelastic T)T the generalized coordinates. The vector h contains all forces. The elastic generalized coordinates qelastic originate from a Ritz approach (relastic = w(r)Tqelastic(t)), describing in our case the linearly assumed deformations of an elastic component. These are pulleys, plates and pins. However, it turned out that at least the elastic pulleys can be approximated very well in a quasi-static way using Maxwell influence numbers.35,38 Elasticity of plates and pins has to be considered because even small kinematical influences within the contacts may change the contact forces significantly. Therefore, the consideration of elasticity is a must to get a good agreement with measurements, especially in the spatial case, where tilting will be possible.

We have unilateral contacts for the pairings (pin ends)/(pulley surfaces) and pins/plates. For these contacts a combination of regularized contact functions, instead of set-valued force laws, and of complementarities was chosen. The combination follows the requirement of minimum computing time. As a result, we only used complementarities for the contacts within those zones, where the chain enters or leaves the pulley. All other contacts are regularized. From this, forces are evaluated straightforward by the force laws on the one side and by Lemke's algorithm for the complementarities on the other side. Two types of torques are taken into consideration, the restoring torques from the non-symmetric local pressure distributions generated in the contacts pins/pulley and from the kinematical process of rolling without sliding of rocker pins on rocker pins.35,63

The dynamics of the rocker pin chain system as a whole will be represented by a set of the equations of motion together with a second set of relative kinematics in normal and tangential directions and finally the set of all complementarity equations. This is written as (100) The abbreviations are clear, q∈ℜf are the generalized coordinates, M∈ℜf,f the symmetric and positive definite mass matrix, W the constraint matrices, λ the constraint forces, g·· the relative accelerations in the contacts, w¯ some external (excitation) terms and λT0 the friction reserves with respect to the boundary of the friction cones.

Equation (100) for the dynamics of a rocker pin chain is solved numerically by evaluating the beginning or the end of a contact event, interpolating these points and solving the complementarity problems by Lemke's algorithm, rearranging the constraint matrices and treating the smooth equations between contact events by a Runge–Kutta 4/5 scheme. In the meantime, this method has been replaced by the prox algorithms, which are more stable and safer and need considerably less computing time. The push-belt problem is evaluated that way.

sec.title: CVT push belts
sec.p:
Contacts of the push belt elements are more complicated (Figure 15). We have a unilateral spatial contact between the element and the pulley, a plane unilateral contact between the element and the ring and five contacts between the elements themselves. The last ones are covered by an empirical non-linear force law. All other contacts are unilateral contacts described by complementarities, then converted and solved by prox functions.66,67 Figure 15.
Contact configurations of push belt elements (p = primary, s = secondary).

The elastic pulley model follows more and less the same ideas as those used for the rocker pin chain. Pulley deformations and the contacts with the belt elements are similar. The pulley sheaves are modelled by rigid cones. For both cones, we approximate the deformation by quasi-static force laws given by the Maxwell numbers. External excitations coming from the CVT environment and acting on the pulleys are taken into account. At the primary pulley, a kinematic excitation is given by an angular velocity ωp (Figure 15). Accordingly, this pulley has no DOF. At the secondary pulley, a kinetic excitation is applied in form of an external torque Ms. Accordingly, this pulley has one DOF qpulley = (αs)T, which is an angle of rotation. The pulley equations of motion gives (101) with the positive definite, constant and diagonal mass matrix Mp. The vector hp is only depending on the time t: hp = hp(t). Thus, the matrices ∂hp∂qp and ∂hp∂up used for the numerical integration are zero matrices.

The elements are modelled by rigid bodies, describing each element m by three DOFs qm = (ym, zm, αm)T. The model of one single element is depicted in Figure 16, where the center S of gravity is determined by the translational positions y and z. The modelling of the whole CVT is performed in the plane containing the axes AA of all elements. Figure 16.
Model of an element.

The M elements are described by the generalized coordinates qe=(q1 T,…,qM T)T, resulting in the equations of motion (102) with the positive definite, constant and diagonal mass matrix Me. The vector he is constant and summarizes forces due to gravity. Thus, the matrices ∂he∂qe and ∂he∂ue are zero matrices.

For the plane model, the two ring packages of the push belt are considered as one virtual ring package having double width. The 9–12 layers of each ring package are homogenized using E A, E I and A ρ as parameters representing the longitudinal stiffness, the bending stiffness and the mass per length, respectively. The magnitudes E and ρ give the modulus of elasticity and the density, A and I denote the cross-sectional area and the moment of inertia of the ring, which is treated as a one-dimensional continuum. Curling up for an unstressed configuration of the beam model is described by the curl radius of the relaxed structure.

A finite element approach is used to describe the ring package elements with the coordinates qi=(yS,zS,ϕS,ɛ~,al,βl,ar,βr)T. Several single finite elements are combined to construct a larger structural element of the ring. It has the global coordinate set qg = (y1, z1, φ1, a1, a2, y2, z2, φ2)T. The first set yS, zS, φS describes the rigid body movements of the finite element, ɛ~ gives an approximation for the longitudinal strain and al, βl, ar, βr describe the bending deflections. The correlation of the two sets follows from the relation qi = Q(qg), the derivatives of which can be used to establish the equations of motion for the single element (i) and for the structural element (g). We have (103) The generalized velocity is u=q·. We may combine these two equations to give the complete set for the ring package66,67 (104) The constraints Wrλ exist between the ring package and the belt elements.

Constraints on elastic structures can be formulated using the schemes derived for rigid body constraints in classical MBSs. Figure 17 displays the contact points on the interacting bodies: the contact point is fixed on the element but sliding on the ring package, whereas the position is defined by the material coordinate sc. It should be mentioned that unilateral as well as bilateral constraints can be treated following the same geometrical ideas. The constraint is specified by the corresponding proximal function.12,68 Figure 17.
Contact between ring structure and element.

In case of the push belt, the contact between the ring package and the elements is assumed to be free of gaps in normal direction of the ring package, so that it can be modelled by a bilateral constraint. In tangential, direction, Coulomb friction is considered, which allows unilaterally defined stick–slip processes. Altogether, we get the following equations (105) where the indices ‘B’, ‘T’ and ‘er’ stand for bilateral, tangential and element/ring package, respectively.

The contacts between the elements and the pulley discs are unilateral in normal and tangential directions. In spite of the fact that within the belt wrap no detachment of an element in normal direction takes place, these kind of events are very important for the belt/pulley zones, where the belt enters or leaves the pulley. We may have contact/detachment in normal and stick–slip by Coulomb friction in tangential directions. Therefore, the contact laws in these cases are (106)

Figure 18 shows two elements in contact. Only contact in normal direction is considered here, because tangential relative motion is circumvented by the guidance of the elements by the ring package and the nipple-hole connection between adjacent elements. The contact between adjacent elements is modelled by a rigid body contact (107) with the gap distances gU,ee between the considered contact points of the interacting elements. Figure 18.
Contact between two elements.

The modelling of the push belt CVT by single components and their interconnections leads to the equations of motion for the plane overall system consisting of the differential equations (108) and the constraints (109) The indices (p, e, r) stand for pulley, element and ring, respectively. The indices (U, B, T) indicate unilateral, bilateral and tangential, respectively. The M are the mass matrices, W the constraint matrices, u=q· are velocities, and λ are constraint forces. The magnitudes g,g· indicate relative displacements and velocities in the contacts and r is an iteration variable, which has been discussed in connection with the equations (74) to (78).

Equation (108) are solved numerically by a time-stepping scheme including prox algorithms. The modular configuration of the model comprising subsystems and constraints enables a refinement or even a substitution of models for single components and interactions in an easy manner. By this, both bodies and contacts can be modelled rigidly or flexibly in a hybrid way. The resulting differential equations have a stiff character.

sec.title: Results for the rocker pin chain
sec.p:
The results of the dynamic model presented are computed for a uniform motion with constant driving speed n1 and an external output torque T2. Figure 19 shows the tensile force of an outer plate of a chain with clasp plates for two different pulley misalignments (T = 150 Nm, n = 600 r/min, i = 1). The comparison of simulation and measurement confirms the mechanical model. Due to the bending forces, the misalignment induces a large gradient of the tensile forces in the spans. Entering a pulley, the shape of a pin changes abruptly because of the sudden growing contact forces. Thus, especially at the beginnings and at the ends of contact arcs, great force peaks appear. Figure 19.
Tensile force of an outer plate with clasp plate, top: misalignment Δz = +1.5 mm, bottom: misalignment Δz = −0.5 mm.

In Pfeiffer69 many parameter variations are considered with the goal to show the possibility of influencing the chain performance significantly by even small changes of chain component geometry. For this purpose, the article concentrates only on the forces of the outer plates, which are the most stressed plates on one side, but represent also a good measure of the chain performance as a whole on the other side. With longer rocker pins and more plates, the tensile forces of a plate can be reduced because of a load distribution on more plates. But if we keep at the same time the cross-section of the pins the same, parts of this reduction by load splitting are lost due to the larger pin bending. Thus, the gain connected with more plates is not so large as often expected. Figure 20 gives an example. Figure 20.
Variation of the number of plates of each link (ired = 1, iCVT = 2.3, n1 = 4000 r/min).

sec.title: Results for the push belts
sec.p: Rocker pin chains are manufactured by various companies with a certain focus at LUK, Germany. Push belt systems are mainly manufactured by VDT-Bosch in the Netherlands, which also operate production facilities in Japan. Measurements are up to now rare. Very good experiments have been performed by Honda in Japan (see Fuji,70 Fuji et al.,71 and Kanchara et al.72), which are available by the cited papers, and also very good measurements have been performed by VDT-Bosch. Therefore, we shall give some general results of simulations and a comparison of theory with the Honda measurements.

Geier67 evaluated many cases by simulation and performed a rather comprehensive study of comparisons with measurements. We shall give only two examples. The first one depicts some simulations for the contacts between the elements themselves and between pulley and element. Figure 21 illustrates the contact forces. Zone 1 corresponds to the free trum, zone 2 the primary pulley, zone 3 the pushing trum and zone 4 the secondary pulley. Figure 21.
Simulation results for two contact forces λN,ee, λN,ep and four torque ratios r, (N = normal, ee = contact element/element and ep = contact element/pulley).

The force λN,ee reflects the normal force in the element/element contact. This force is zero in the free trum and remains zero along the length of approach path of the primary pulley due to the fact that the elements remain separated when entering the primary pulley. But then, the contact force is built up and leaves the primary pulley with a value, which is maintained during the complete push trum phase, making this trum to a kind of pressure bar. Entering the secondary pulley (zone 4) results in a maximum of the force λN,ee first due to the influence of the pressure transmitted to the belt by the deformed pulley and second due to a prestressing effect by the ring package. This is all very plausible from physical arguments and also confirmed by the simulations.

The contact force λN,ep between pulley and element is of course zero for the two trums in zones 1 and 3 and non-zero within the pulleys in zones 2 and 4. The results illustrate the typical characteristics known also from rocker pin chains. In entering and leaving a pulley, we always get a sharp rise of the contact forces between pulley and the elements, which are then a bit reduced within the pulley wrap arc. These forces do not depend very much on the torque ratio r, whereas the element/element contact force λN,ee increases considerably with the torque ratio.

The second example taken from Geier67 concerns a comparison between simulations and the Honda measurements published in Fujii,70 Fujii et al.,71 and Kanchara et al.72 Figure 22 gives a comparison, which is very good. The measurements within the push trum are not constant but show a dip, which according to the papers of Fujii,70 Fujii et al.,71 and Kanchara et al.72 does not correspond to reality. The measurements, which are really complicated to perform, could not give realistic values for that regime. Figure 22.
Verification of the element/element contact force λN,ee for four torque ratios r (N = normal, ee = contact element/element).

sec.title: Roller coaster
sec.p:
One of the challenging practical examples concerning unilateral multibody theory are roller coasters. In Germany, we have among others a system called Wild Mouse. The trajectory configuration for this Wild Mouse is depicted in Figure 23 together with the vehicle system. The track generates frequent and abrupt changes of the vehicle's course, resulting in a special thrill for the passengers. Thereby, and due to the slackness of the wheel rail contact, sequences of impacts with friction take place, producing a significant amount of load and stress to the wheels and the undercarriage system. Each carriage possesses four packages each with six wheels coming out with altogether 24 wheel-track contacts of a spatial character. Figure 23.
‘Wild Mouse’ and roller coaster carriage.

The six carriage wheels per wheel package are necessary to keep the carriage safely on the track for all possible accelerations, which means two wheels on three sides of the track, top, bottom, side. The model includes the vehicle body and the two axes, front and transaxle, and the four wheel packages, all considered to be rigid bodies, body and axes with six DOFs each. Between vehicle body and the axes, we have force laws in the form of a spring–damper arrangement. Figure 24 illustrates the arrangement of the body–axes- and of the axis-wheel-configuration. Figure 24.
Models of axes and wheels.

The wheels, manufactured from plastic materials, are modelled as sliding elements due to their very small masses in comparison with the mass of the axes. In addition, we assume rolling without sliding, which is realistic for nearly all operation conditions. The wheel-track contact thus includes three contact possibilities, namely contact/detachment, stiction/sliding in lateral direction and rolling without sliding in trajectory direction (Figure 24). For the first case, impacts with friction are considered, for the second case, the relevant complementarities and for the third case, we introduce rolling friction in the form of an empirical coefficient. The derivation of the equations of motion is straightforward by first modelling the bodies, connecting them either with smooth or set-valued force laws and by establishing the accompanying geometrical and kinematical algebraic equations.

A model has been established with 18 DOFs and 24 potential contacts. Direct measurements of the roller contacts are either impossible or very difficult. Therefore, the vehicle has been simply equipped with acceleration sensors for measuring the lateral motion. Figure 23 depicts the location of the sensor and Figure 25 compares these measurements with the simulation. The agreement is very good and validates the model of the overall dynamics. On the basis of the simulation model, some improvements of the roller design could be performed. Figure 25.
Comparison with measurements for the lateral motion.

sec.title: Drop tower hydraulics
sec.p:
The second example is the hydraulic safety brake system of a fun ride, the free fall tower. Figure 26 shows such a tower. Under normal operation conditions, the passenger cabin is lifted by a cable winch to a height of about 60 m. Subsequently, the cabin is released and falls down nearly undamped. Before reaching the ground, the normal brake system stops the cabin softly via the cable winch. For safety reasons, a redundant brake system is necessary. In case of failure of the regular brakes or a cable rupture, the safety brake system has to catch the cabin even under disadvantageous conditions. Figure 26.
Drop tower.

The safety brake system is a hydraulic system which moves brake blocks via hydraulic cylinders. For this purpose, steel blades are fixed to the cabin. The steel blades fall into a guide rail with the brake blocks fixed to it. They are closed by very large spring forces and opened by hydraulic cylinders, which must operate very fast and synchronously. Under normal operation conditions, the brake blocks are moved out of the guide rail shortly before the cabin reaches them. Only in case of some failure, the safety brakes remain closed and the cabin is stopped by the friction forces. Due to the very short opening time of the brake, the hydraulic cylinders move fast and reach the end stop with high velocities. In some cases, the resulting impact forces have caused damages to the cylinders.

The safety brakes are designed in modules, where each module contains the mechanical and the complete hydraulic part of the brake. According to the functionality of the passenger cabin, they must be arranged in a vertical sense, one on the top of the other. Depending on the height of the drop tower, one needs usually about six to seven of these brake segments. The brakes are realized in such a way that they safely catch the passenger cabin even under very disadvantageous conditions like rope rupture at maximum height in combination with rain.

Hydraulic systems can conveniently be modelled as non-smooth systems leading to computing times up to three orders of magnitude smaller than the classical approach as often used in commercial codes. Therefore, we establish a hydraulic model on the basis of non-smooth and smooth hydraulic components according to Figure 27 (see for example Pfeiffer13). The underlying mathematical model for one segment including the oil supply component consists of 202 differential equations; for each further module not containing the oil supply, we get 132 differential equations. For seven brake segments, we have thus altogether 994 differential equations, which correspond to the number of hydraulic DOFs. Mechanics is involved only with a few DOFs for the drop tower model. Figure 27.
Hydraulic model of the drop tower safety brakes.

The model has been verified by measurements. Figure 28 shows the result. The opening of the cylinders start at t = 0.1 s. After that point, the cylinders move, thus increasing the pressure due to the growing spring force in the cylinders. After having reached the end stop, the oil pressure becomes stable at a level of 120 bar. This large pressure is kept constant, because the oil cannot flow back after the check valves have been closed in the feed lines. The agreement between the simulations and measurements is very good, confirming the theory. The simulations have been used to improve the time behaviour of the hydraulic modules in connection with the brakes. Figure 28.
Comparison Measurements/simulations.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The equations of motion for non-smooth MBSs are presented and possible numerical solution procedures discussed. The equations of motion may be given in the classical form including smooth and non-smooth constraints, the last ones as complementarities, or they may be formulated as MDEs in connection with a prox-representation of the constraints. The last-mentioned formulation is much better suited for modern numerical methods, which are not presented here. Some literature is given. These numerical algorithms go from event-driven to time-stepping schemes, the last ones in combination with an augmented Lagrange approach. At the time being, this seems to be the best and fastest numerical solution possibility. The theory is illustrated by four large examples from industry.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
